comments.commentBody: Good post.

I can understand that it may make you feel good, but it doesn't reflect reality, or at least not a very critical look at it. Let's take the statement that "renewables can generate 80 percent of our electricity in 2050". Okay, well what happens between now and then? And where does the other 20% come from? 80% is great, and it would be wonderful if we can get there. But we need to start cutting greenhouse emissions NOW.

The safety record of well regulated nukes is beyond reproach - no other industry can touch it. And nuclear technology is very affordable, it is nuclear politics that are expensive. It is fossil fuels that we can no longer afford. We need nuclear to carry the load that renewables cannot.
Well regulated nukes? In a world run by Tea Parties and assorted Ayn Rand type crackpots? Sell that one to those who survived Fukishima.

Well, we do not love nukes. The discussion centers on whether nuclear energy and/or natural gas need to be used as we transition to renewable forms of energy. The argument is that renewable forms are not yet advanced enough to provide energy to a growing world population. You are correct that there are many powerful economic forces impeding a transition to renewable energy.

This is a good, categorical, to the point article which is very much needed in this discussion.

@D. Martin -

Yes, "over the longer term".

In the interim I expect it's going to get messy. At the present time there may be some shore properties owned by families of very modest means where it's been in the family for several generations. Soon they'll not be able to afford flood insurance and at some point after that they'll get wiped out by a storm. Other owners with more robust financial resources may make it through a cycle or two of storm damage, repairs, and increased insurance cost, but at some point they, too, will have to give up. Of course, it's anyone's guess how long potential buyers will ignore the implacable truth, but, over time, a willing seller will have to lower the asking price substantially (then drastically) before a willing buyer will purchase (and insure) an endangered property. And, Mr. Martin, you're right; eventually the last to leave will be the affluent who tire of continually dumping money into an asset with a steeply declining market value, no matter how marvelous the view.

While that's a somber scenario for Americans deal with, I would leave to readers' imaginations the truly catastrophic impact on low-lying communities such as Bangladesh.

But what's the "longer term"? Not likely in five to ten years. On the other hand, certainly within 150 years. I like to see how stories turn out, but neither you nor I, nor likely anyone reading our remarks today will be around to see the really bad stuff.

"Decay" is not quite the right word.  Nature can make a different use of those shorelines and barrier islands, taking away and depositing (the north end of Sandy Hook is growing) as currents dictate.  We are already slowly retreating from the shore, as waterside homes are sliced away to create homes and inland areas turn to buyouts.  Immediately after Sandy, I thought  it would take several more such storms to really affect shore development.  After seeing the efforts still being expended, I think one more storm like Sandy would end the "rebuild everything" initiatives.  But Sandy was very unusual.  When will another storm come straight in to the shore like that>

If I recall correctly the Florida Windstorm Insurance Program is underfunded.  Insurers in the state are assessed a fee on homeowner's policies to help fund the wind pool and when "the big one hits" insurers will be required to pay the shortfall.  I know that many of the big insurers, including the one I used to work for, will no longer write new policies in the state.   Insurance is all about risk and if one desires to live in a high risk area then they should be willing to pay the higher premiums that come with that risk.

There's been relative quiet about expanded flood zones and loss of flood insurance subsidies in Florida. In some areas (including mine), waterfront and barrier island properties tend to be expensive enough that the residents self-insure. Politically, windstorm insurance has been more of a concern.

Presumably, the next storm to severely affect a large urban area in the Florida peninsula will bring huge drops in property-tax revenues, and probably will not bring the generous federal aid that speeded recovery from past storms. At least one Florida coastal congressman opposes such aid, anyway. m

Electric utilities already seem under pressure to trim trees and take other measures to reduce the likelihood or extent of storm-caused power outages like those of the past decade.

Over the longer term, as sea level rises and beaches disappear, I suppose that the affluent will move inland, leaving the shorelines to decay.
Please walk us through the time frame again.

My grandmother born in 1872 was a radical for her day. she did not put up with misogynists. In her younger days she had been a leader in the community. She was a country girl originally and was the one that would cut the heads off the chickens. So both my mother and my were hell raisers, and my mother would stand up to just about anyone.
Mother had been a city junior tennis champion, was a good golfer, used to go wild boar hunting near Salinas, rode horses on roundups in the Sierra Foothills on a friends ranch, and helped build a mountain cabin.

Several years ago in the 50s she transferred from one GS job to another in a different city. They tried to tell her she had to use her husbands last name on her job title, he was my stepfather, whom she married many years before while I was in the AF on the east coast.

That did not sit well with her at all, and she really raised hell about it and got her way.
Fortunately she had seniority by then, so got away with it, but having been raised in such a household, with these women, I really had a hard time understanding the thinking behind such rules.
Lots of stars--You are exactly right.  And breastfeeding certainly does not keep a baby from having colicky spells of screaming wakefulness, either.

While I agree that breastfeeding is by no means insurance against colicky babies (I had two, the second one required swaddling and the baby dance for 6 months from 5pm to 9 pm every. night.), I often tell anyone who is even contemplating parenthood that prolactin from breastfeeding is what keeps us from killing our children in infancy. Despite the utter exhaustion, the prolactin from my let-down reflex would help keep me attached to the baby that moments ago I had been so angry at, and allow me to breathe. Even if the baby kept screaming, I felt reconnected.
That said, sometimes the screaming got too much, or we were in a situation (like halfway home from a out of state car trip) where that wasn't possible, and stopping to nurse wouldn't affect the colic screaming. Then it's time to just allow yourself to be angry and frustrated, cry right along with the baby, and if necessary, blast loud punk rock through the car speakers to drown out the both of you! ("I wanna be sedated" being my anthem of choice--this is also great for toddler tantrum time!)

I only experienced the calming effects of breast feeding with my second and third children, who slept with us until they were three months old.  It was a nightmare getting up and down all night with our first.

Before I read the biographical note, I thought you were the infant's mother, and my first reaction was "she must not be breastfeeding". I say this not just because breastfeeding is a way to connect the baby with the intense reassurance of Mommy's scent/feel/taste/voice/appearance, but also because a breastfed child is so quickly soothed.

In German, the verb "to breastfeed" is "stillen" -- with the connotation of "to quieten", as in the phrase "still waters run deep".

Yet another benefit of the original Nature-designed infant nutrition.

My wife is from Singapore.
My children were born in Singapore, and one of them spent months in a Singapore hospital.
During that time I asked a lot of questions about costs and outcomes. Learning how their system works. And with that up front experience I am entirely certain that Mr. Carroll is basically correct, while the Republicans have no clue how Singapore's health care actually functions.

I would go farther than Mr. Carroll though in emphasizing one key characteristic of the Singaporean system. The culture is primarily Chinese, and certainly mostly southeast Asian. That part of the world has strong traditions of respecting one's elders, and in return expecting to be taken care of by the wisdom of those elders. For about 50 years Singapore was ruled as an effective dictatorship, one guy in charge. But he ran possibly the most benevolent dictatorship in recorded history, and as a result was hugely respected. So the citizens of Singapore don't hope that their government will take care of them, or even expect it... it is simply assumed. Part and parcel of its existence as a country.

Such an attitude permeates the interaction between the citizenry and the government in a way that is probably incomprehensible to most Republicans. Certainly when applied to healthcare there are many facets there that are basically taken for granted, that if implemented in America would be decried as communist takeovers.

The CONSTRUCTION costs per watt hour capacity may be at parity.
However, the GENERATING costs are entirely different.
Generating costs for solar photovoltaics are essentially zero.
They don't require any fuel, just sunshine. And they produce no waste.
Nukes require highly processed uranium fuel and no one has figured out how to deal with waste that remains dangerously radioactive for millennia. Generating costs include fuel and waste disposal.
$10 billion for 1 GW reactor? Not even close. A modern one like Westinghouse's AP1000 can be built for $5 billion in the US and for under $2 billion in China due to lower labor costs.
Chernobyl and Fukishima political problems? Tell that whopper to Patch Adams and see what you get.

Nuclear power, in its current form, may have priced itself out of the market. It costs about $10 billion to build a 1 GW nuclear plant, which works out to $10 per watt. Solar is getting down to $3 per watt. But the nuke can run 24 hrs/day and the solar plant can average about 8. So the generation costs are reaching parity.

Many of the problems cited about atomic energy are primarily political, but they are still problems. Solar has lots of political problems too like allocating land for the panels and building out massive transmission lines to distribute the power all over the country. It's just amazing how much resistance locals put up against building power lines.

Solar power should exploit the vast desert southwest. We will need about 40,000 square miles for two thousand gigawatts of generation. Current generation is about one thousand gigawatts, but we will need twice as much to compensate for nighttime. The desert lovers will have to compromise and a few lizards may go extinct. Storage is still a problem. I like heat storage (molten salts) using simple thermal solar as opposed to photovoltaics and exotic batteries that require scarce materials.

At current costs, we will need about $6 trillion for the buildout and probably another $1 trillion for storage (my guess). That's a lot money but this is going to take 50 years. At $140 billion/year, its doable. So lets's get started already!

Nice article! Very common sense approach to a heavily flawed technology. Nukes take up the lions share of subsidies, double that of wind and solar per kilowatt-hour (see Union of Concerned Scientists/Earth Track study on nuke subsidies). Nuke subsidies come in at 6 cents a kWhe, more than half the average kWhe sold in the U.S. (about 11 cents).
Nukes are so expensive that different nuke industry leaders have said that they will not build any more nukes unless the U.S. Government fully guarantees them.

You said, "The Tea Party show the suicidal optimism typical of hate groups, with its insistence on destroying Obamacare even if they have to destroy the government along with it."

I say it's the other way around: The Tea Party is focused on destroying the government so, of course, a successful government program like Obamacare must be destroyed.

Yes, I remember TMI. Pretty much everything possible went wrong, and _still_ no one was harmed.

Hey, what's worse? An occasional TMI incident, or catastrophic climate change, killing all life and turning the Earth into a Venus-like planet?

Sorry Mark H., you're not entitled to your own facts. Those containment items at Fukishima were ones just like those used in the U.S. and made by American companies. And Chernobyl, you gotta be kidding.

Lots of things are prone to human error and can cost people's lives. It would take quite a while to come up with a complete list. I'll start: guns, DWI, cars, food poisoning, surgery, medicines, construction work, trains, subways, airplanes, . . ., you get the idea.

Remember Three Mile Island? A near nuclear meltdown happened not too far from where I lived in 1979. Most people do not remember it or talk about it today. But I do remember. Because what I personally went through in those few days after the accident I am not a fan of nuclear energy. It is prone with the possibility of human error that can cost people's lives. Nuclear energy is not an option in my book.
It's not a question of copyright, but of plagiarism. That's why it's important to reference the original if you display your version, at least professionally.
The question isn't about copyright law. It's about the ethics of stealing credit for a work that wasn't your idea or creation.

The value added to the product is not in the raw material. It is in the skill of the photographer and the technique his applies to his craft.
The scene is the raw material.
You wouldn't tell one artist he couldn't use charcoal on canvas because another artist had already done so.

The notion of not being (ethically) able to photograph a scene from the same vantage point as a professional photographer (then crop it so it looks even more like the original) seems ridiculous.

How would one manage to get camera placement within a millimeter of the original? How would one take the photo at the exact time of day, the exact day of the year, with the sun and clouds and breezes cooperating to replicate the original instant the professional's shutter clicked? With each passing day the second photo would be a less exact likeness of the first.

Who could stand where Ansel Adams stood to take any of his famous shots and replicate his work closely enough to infringe on his copyright?

Thanks for writing about this, Gail. Many women still living can remember when "women's libbers" were laughed at. (In red states they probably still do that.)

I remember my own parents encouraging all their daughters to marry doctors, never considering the possibility that we could become doctors ourselves. We were supposed to be helpmates to successful men rather than have our own ambitions. The only success we were supposed to have was as mothers and wives.

I remember going on marches in the 70's and participating in consciousness raising groups. I remember feeling that Martin Luther King Jr.'s speech "I Have a Dream" inspired women to dream too of equality.

There has been some progress but it's sad how far short we are from the goals we had back then. There has been backlash and fighting the small old battles over and over in many places. I guess I have to be grateful for small improvements but I live with disappointments and disillusionment...
Note: who is The Colonel? Question: why should we care?

NOTE: The Colonel is a professional op ed writer and frequently comments on academia.

The president is right although scaredy cat that he is he had to wait until his second term to say it. What a wimp we have for president - he makes only safe decisions.

No wonder the law profession is foundering. - The Colonel

I can understand that it may make you feel good, but it doesn't reflect reality, or at least not a very critical look at it. Let's take the statement that "renewables can generate 80 percent of our electricity in 2050". Okay, well what happens between now and then? And where does the other 20% come from? 80% is great, and it would be wonderful if we can get there. But we need to start cutting greenhouse emissions NOW.

The safety record of well regulated nukes is beyond reproach - no other industry can touch it. And nuclear technology is very affordable, it is nuclear politics that are expensive. It is fossil fuels that we can no longer afford. We need nuclear to carry the load that renewables cannot.

I'm too mesmerised by what's going on in Korea.

Canned Dates
suejean here, pretty weepy as well.

Laszlo:

Wonderful!

Of course I'm more familiar with some of the Spanish language renditions of the song.

It is a standard and has been covered by myriad artists, although I did not know it had become so popular in other parts of the world.

A beautiful song in any language!

Lasz, Of course, we're aware of your enviable linguistic abilities, however, and perhaps EEN can weigh in here, how was NKC's Hispanic version of the song you downloaded, when compared to his decidedly embarrassing English/French version of "Darling, Je Vous Aime Beaucoup?"
To my ear, it didn't sound all that bad...his Espanol, e.g. not his Francais renditions?

Howie

Before diving into today's puzzle, I need to take care of some unfinished business from yesterday.

Leapy,

Try this on for size:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BxZunRe-sq0
or this:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GOc83mhAMXk

There is a small difference in lyrics between the two versions.

After a little research I discovered that this song, composed by Cuban song-writer Osvaldo Farrés (1903-1985) titled "Tres palabras," was made popular by the 1946 Disney movie "Make Mine Music" under the English title "Without You."

Strangely, the movie was never shown in Hungary but the song became very popular, with lyrics provided by one György G. Dénes.

Sr. Farrés escaped from Cuba with his wife in 1962 never to return, and died in West New York, NJ, in 1985.

Here is the original Spanish-language version:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z7riFC3yP6Y

English lyrics: http://tinyurl.com/lf3svoe

If you'd like, I can also provide Hungarian lyrics of both versions, and if you ask me nicely, I can also re-translate into English just for the fun of it, and to see what a huge difference poetic license can make, although the substance remains.

HALO! XACTO what we want in a SATXWDP!
We really think highly of Healy!
There ARNO words to describe this puz, bec it's me bloomin' cup OFTEA with a loverly SCONE on the side!
You may even go so far as to call it my Honky 'ONKEY Serenade?
Time to TOSSDOWN my Armagnac to toast Frederick J. for this HEADS-up creation!
Oh, MTF, FYI, my BD girl, Librarose, acquiesced by permitting yours truly to submit this comment inSPITE of my questionable state of sobriety.
Oye! 17A could've been either Vanilla Egg Cream or Chocolate Floats!
I GUT no MOT to say...

ONCUE very much!

WHH

Very little evidence? You have, with all due respect, got to be kidding.

Not only climate change, by the way - but pollution from all kinds of carbon burning - if you can't wrap your mind around melting glaciers, increasingly terrible storms and unpredictable weather including droughts and floods that threaten our cities and our farms and the production of the food we eat - for pete's sake will you look at the simple and devastating impact of pollution on land, sea and sky? Cancers are increasingly common and entire species are going extinct.

We're in big trouble. And we should start by thinking very seriously about certain religious and political agitation against birth control and women's reproductive freedom, since the planet itself is at risk.

Instead, we have reactionary religious and political parties - not so coincidentally, it appears, in bed with the oil, coal and fracking industries, which not only ignore climate science, pollution and the devastation of our planet but which are also trying to force women to have more babies.

This is insane.
Yes, MTF, he was brainwashed, but I preferred him as Elizabeth Taylor's toy.
PS to MTF, Lately, I've been watching re-runs of Murder She Wrote.

This article is concerned with Microsoft and Steve Ballmer. Why talk about Intel which is a chip manufacturer? By the way, as Apple's fortunes rise so should Intel's as Apple computers have relied upon Intel processors for the last seven years. In the tech industry, by 2030 it very well could be "Apple who?" Oh and Steve Jobs has been dead for nearly two years.

No reason to obfuscate things with politics.   There are plenty of examples of wildly successful CEOs in innovative businesses who are conservatives of various stripes.     I'd also be tempted to correct an error in your post but the moderators don't always allow for that.

Paul Otellini and Steve Ballmer are conservative Republicans. Why would anyone higher a conservative in a business famous for rapid change? They are better suited for positions in industries that change slowly and require someone much less capable than Steve Jobs.

It should be noted that they both milked their jobs for all the money they could before it became obvious that that their companies had struck an iceberg. They are responsible for their companies hitting an iceberg. It was their job to plot a path to new sources revenue. Their failure at their jobs has long been obvious. If they had been lower level employees, they would have been fired a long time ago.

As an example of a lack of change one can compare Apple to Intel. While Apple came up with such new sources of revenue as iPhone, iPad, iTunes, etc. Intel came out with a microprocessor, a microprocessor and a microprocessor. Now Intel's microprocessor business is slowly getting destroyed as the ARM microprocessor eats more and more of their lunch. By 2030 it will be Intel who?

Leapy,

In many states, "issue" is now construed to include adopted as well as biological offspring.

If you're one of those who thinks adoption was intended by the creator to be limited to one man and one woman -- and must therefore be disallowed for tennis equipment -- I don't want to hear it. We try to keep this a politics-free zone!
MTF, sounds as if you have some kind of a racket going there.

Interestingly, if you take the Across entry in the extreme NE and the Across entry in the extreme SW, change the letter in the SW corner to S (because it's not in the East), and put them side by side, you get

GRAF SPEE

Ryan, I don't know if you enjoy watching women's tennis, which can involve more finesse than the men's game and is also easier to follow because the ball does not necessarily travel as fast. But if you do, and if the cross of GRAF and FOSSE discombobulated you, do follow three simple steps:

1. Get video of the Women's Singles Finals of 1988's major tennis tournaments and that year's Olympic games.
2. Sit down.
3. Watch them.

As for FOSSE, I will let someone else advise you what to watch. The entirety of what I know about choreography is that a friend once pointed out Jerome Robbins behind us waiting to be let in to a theater (I wouldn't have known him from The Most Interesting Man In The World), she refused to let me speak to him when they finally unlocked the doors, I stepped to the side and motioned him to enter, he demurred, and I told him it was my honor to allow him to precede me.

-- [Mostof] Thatjazz-y FOSSE

I was just talking about paradoxes the other day, and here I see XENO staring back at me. IMAGINE THAT. Upon finishing, I didn't think I'd GHAN Astray, but alas, the GRAF/FOSSE cross gave me A RUDE awakening. As for the grid itself, this one was obviously culled from the A-LIST. Tiger actually is Asian, in large measure... did you hear who won the 2008 U.S. Open? It was a Thai (well, kind of).

I like how we have TOSS DOWN, and then, with HEADS, another toss down. U entered ONCE, ON CUE, to accompany the ON-KEY mONKEY hiding in the SE. On the anagram front, a gently ruffled STENO PAD makes NOTEPADS. STEINMART sounds like a tavern to me (don't order too many of those malts... you'll get the CHOCOLATE SHAKES).

As A RULE, I CARE not for drab puzzles. EUR offering, Mr. Healy, was anything but: there ARNO missteps here, just INTRAsting and clever entries. AMPLE fun.
He's the Commentator in Chief.

The President has absolutely no power over whether law schools require two or three years from their students.  May I respectfully suggest that the President concentrate on issues, such as NSA abuses, where he does have the power to make changes?  He wasn't elected to be a commentator.

Solar power is a disruptive technology not because it has the ability to meet our energy needs, but because it is guaranteed a price higher than the value it provides to the grid.  Without a revolution in storage technology it provides neither dependable baseload or dispatchable peakload generation.  Other generation is expected to compensate for it and wind through load-following.  That means less coal and nuclear perhaps, but a vast amount more natural gas fired generation.

Penny???

Well, I thought there was a little wordplay in 53A, because at first glance, I was thinking of dishes that serve two, like Pekin duck or Chateaubriand.

I had a friend in New Haven who fenced competitively, even made the Olympic "B" team. The few times I saw a competition, I always expected that someone would trip over the loops of cord on the floor when hey were in retreat. By now, they must have retracting cords.
